body: AT last count, the guest list tonight includes Matilda, Geb Ra, Murphy and his brother Ed, and Lucy. Before midnight strikes, the guests will feast on a special cheesecake made of cottage cheese, American cheese and Cheez Whiz That's at a hotel in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. In Flatbush, at a rival hotel, the guests will be serenaded by the staff with
title: COPING; Living Large, Barking Loud

body: On the coldest Christmas in more than a decade, the hungry and the homeless began lining up early yesterday for hot meals. Outside the Y.W.C.A. at the corner of Third and Atlantic Avenues in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, the temperature was 19 degrees at 10 a.m. and the line of people waiting for the annual Christmas meal stretched
title: Another Tradition: Refuge in a Shelter

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: After a quarter of a century in which community opposition, lack of government financing and other obstacles thwarted the development of three prime patches at the edge of downtown Brooklyn, New York State moved yesterday to spur housing and retail projects on the sites. State officials invited proposals from developers to buy and build on one of
title: State Seeks Plans for Neglected Brooklyn Area

body: IN Italo Calvino's 1972 novel, ''Invisible Cities,'' a fictional Marco Polo recounts his journeys through imagined lands and their dreamlike capitals. In these mysterious places, people mingle in a caldron of exuberance and suffering, against a backdrop of clashing architecture and sensuous detail. Then Polo comes to a region called Trude, where
title: Landmarks for Common Folk

body: NEW JERSEY TRENTON: LANDMARK CUSTODY RULING STANDS -- A lesbian who won the right to visit her former partner's children praised a move by the United States Supreme Court that lets the New Jersey ruling stand, the woman's lawyer said yesterday. The woman will continue to see the 6-year-old twins every other weekend, a custody arrangement approved
title: Metro Briefing

body: ON a stormy evening last May, silvery voices could be heard floating down the halls of Public School 321 in Park Slope. ''To-may-to! To-mah-to! Po-tay-to! Po-tah-to! ''Let's call the whole thing off . . . '' As the children sang, their parents drank coffee and ate Pepperidge Farm cookies in the auditorium. Standing among them, a youthful-looking
title: The Quest to Reinvent John Jay

body: HARBOR seals bobbing in the water. Freighters from all over the world floating by. Cormorants spreading their wings on pier pilings and diving for fish. A sandy beach, right in the backyard. This is Brooklyn? Dr. June Reinisch, 57, and her husband, Dr. Leonard Rosenblum, 64, have been privy to these views of Gravesend Bay -- sometimes using a
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sea Gate; 'Hamptons West' in Brooklyn

body: Name: Eddie Klaynberg Age: 17 Born in N.Y.C.: 1983, Brooklyn Neighborhood: Upper East Side Who he is: High school student Then: ''I board at LaSalle Academy out on Long Island during the week. I'm taking chemistry, math, American history and English. I've always been into film, so maybe I'll do N.Y.U.'s film program. My dad's a contractor, and he
title: The Difference A Year Makes

author: Diane Cardwell is an editor at the magazine.
body: A few years ago, when I moved near Smith Street -- a dusty stretch running through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens -- it seemed happily mired in the 1950's. Dotted with members-only social clubs and old men playing cards in front of shuttered storefronts, the area felt untouched by the relentless pace of Manhattan
title: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00; A Street Grows In Brooklyn

body: Much like Manhattan, Brooklyn has never had a boroughwide multiple listing of homes for sale. Now, reflecting a lack of inventory at a time when prices -- especially in Brooklyn's historic brownstone districts -- have been rising, the three multiple listing services that loosely divide the borough plan to merge by the end of the year. ''The idea is
title: Residential Real Estate; Multiple Listings Sought For Homes in Brooklyn

body: The flags hanging from the windows of homes lining the only cobblestone blocks in Brooklyn Heights all bear the same Revolutionary War motto, ''Don't Tread on Me.'' The flag-waving residents want to stop a park they fear will bring thousands of people walking along their streets every weekend. On the waterfront below Brooklyn Heights, a
title: As Some Fight A Park Plan, Its Supporters See Elitism; Many in Brooklyn Hts. Fear Hordes of Visitors

body: The gas explosion that leveled one town house, destroyed a neighboring one and killed three people in Brooklyn last month was probably primed by a leaky pipe in the first house's basement and ignited by someone flipping a light switch, fire marshals said yesterday. The marshals reached their conclusion by the process of elimination, after ruling
title: Leaky Basement Pipe Blamed in Blast That Killed Three in Brooklyn

title: EATING OUT; Touring the Boroughs

body: THINK disasters. Think ''Ghostbusters.'' Put them together and you've just -- too glibly -- summed up Raymond M. Downey's job as chief of Rescue Operations for the New York City Fire Department. It is a job that on a good day makes you feel like a lifesaver, and on bad days, like the day of a Brooklyn brownstone collapse that killed three last
title: PUBLIC LIVES; When Disaster Strikes, He's a Lifesaver

body: The primary natural gas lines leading into two Brooklyn town houses destroyed Tuesday in an explosion did not leak during pressure tests yesterday, several officials involved in the investigation said. The tests undercut a potential explanation for the explosion -- that a leaking service line might have saturated one of the buildings with gas,
title: Tests Rule Out Some Causes in Brooklyn Blast

body: A wall and two floors collapsed yesterday at an architectural salvage shop in the East Village whose showrooms were loaded with cast-iron fireplaces, Victorian bathtubs, original porcelain New York street signs and Tiffany windows. The damage left the building listing dangerously, forcing the evacuation of 51 apartments in three nearby buildings
title: Collapse Dooms Building and Its Treasures

body: The day was winding down on Tuesday, and life on State Street in Brooklyn unfolded as it would on just about any July evening. In his garden apartment at 428 State Street, Noel Rosenbower watered the plants and then braised a rabbit for a small birthday party on his backyard patio. Karen Richter, at 397 State Street, got ready to watch a video,
title: Block's Hard-Won Spirit Torn in Fatal Blast

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. and Vietnam Reach Broad Trade Agreement The United States and Vietnam have completed a trade agreement that would allow generally unfettered commerce between the two nations for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War, people involved in the negotiations said. Vietnamese and American officials reached the agreement
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: Three bodies were recovered yesterday from the rubble of a Brooklyn town house that exploded Tuesday night, and fire investigators said they strongly suspected that a gas leak had caused the blast. ''That's the main possibility,'' Chief Fire Marshal Louis F. Garcia said. ''We're not really looking at anything else.'' Fire officials suspect a gas
title: Investigators Suspect That Gas Leak Was Cause of the Blast

body: Despite an intensive weeklong campaign to round up truants, more than 130,000 students in kindergarten through 12th grade -- nearly 40 percent -- are missing from the most ambitious summer school program in New York City's history, the Board of Education said yesterday. The poor attendance is a costly and potentially embarrassing culmination to
title: Summer School Truancy Rate In New York Near 40 Percent

body: Three people were missing and feared dead last night after an explosion destroyed a three-story red-brick building near downtown Brooklyn and heavily damaged the house next door, the authorities said. The 7:45 p.m. explosion, which reduced 420 State Street in Boerum Hill to a pile of beams and bricks and damaged its neighbor, 418 State Street,
title: Blast Levels a Brooklyn Building; 3 People Are Missing

body: As firefighters and trained dogs searched for her body in the rubble of the leveled building at 420 State Street, Noreen Davidsen was some 60 miles away at her new cottage in, as her answering machine put it, ''beautiful Ocean Grove.'' Yesterday afternoon she had driven away from the garden apartment in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn, leaving
title: Residents' Thoughts Turn to Missing Couple

body: They both plan for it and plant for it now, those hardy gardeners of State Street, between Hoyt and Bond Streets in Brooklyn's Boerum Hill. After winning the title of the Greenest Block in Brooklyn for two years running, the block was hit by a roving pack of plant thieves last year. The problems, unfortunately, are continuing. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Brooklyn Bridge, the Magazine: Born 1995; Suspended, 2000

body: THERE isn't enough room in the Manhattan Yellow Pages to detail my attempts to get a working telephone in my new apartment in Brooklyn. title: COPING; Feeling Like an Orphan in Ma Bell's Domain

body: The bagel. The knish. The pepperoni slice. To couple the words ''Brooklyn'' and ''food'' is to evoke these legendary immigrant-inspired snacks that over the last century have filled the bellies of locals and injected pizazz into palates of Americans from Memphis to Malibu. But lest anyone think Brooklyn's gastronomic glories are limited to these
title: CITY LORE; Brooklyn on 10,000 Calories a Day

body: WHEN girls from around New York City, juniors in public schools, sat down to write about ''A Woman I Admire'' they chose subjects as celebrated as Princess Di, as memorable as Hester Prynne and as ancient as Eve. But many of the girls, in an annual essay contest sponsored by Barnard College and the CBS Foundation, wrote about mothers: mothers who
title: FIRST PERSON; M Is For . . .

title: A Great Bridge Builder Deserves Name on the Map

body: GO out in Brooklyn? On the weekend? For groovy New Yorkers, that was once an unbearably tepid proposition. Russian immigrants may drink vodka in Brighton Beach leisure palaces, and Trinidadians let loose to soca near Nostrand Avenue. But the students, artists and hipsters seeking the cultural edge started their evenings on the subway to the Village
title: Brooklyn Nights Turn Brighter

body: IN the granite grip of winter, the sunny notion of a dessert named St.-Tropez (more widely known as tarte tropezienne) has undeniable appeal. It is an immense round of buttery brioche, dimpled like focaccia, sugared on top and filled with satiny rum-spiked custard. Think of an oversize Boston cream pie with more substance but no chocolate, simple
title: TEMPTATION; A Taste Of St.-Tropez

body: The detritus of urban life litters the streets of Boerum Hill: candy wrappers, soda cans and other jetsam, much of it cast off by people walking through on their way to downtown Brooklyn. In other neighborhoods near commercial districts, the Department of Sanitation puts out litter baskets and empties them daily. And shopkeepers can ''adopt'' trash
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Avid Wastebasket Adopters Get Hard Time From City

body: HERE are three recent novels full of vivid detail, weaving New York City life through larger tales of crime and corruption, on gangland life at the turn of the century, young unorthodox detectives from Brooklyn and a corrupt precinct of the New York City Police Department. title: BOOKSHELF; Tales of Corruption And Crime
